question: How come the sun didn't used to shine in here?
answer: 'cause when we bought the house it was Autumn. This is summer. Feed the dogs.

question: Right.
answer: Do you see the kids?

question: Probably out in the back yard.
answer: In Amity, you say 'Yahd.'

question: The kids are in the yahd, playing near the cah. How's that sound?
answer: Like you're from N'Yawk.

question: Give me 30 years, I'll get it. Did you burn another kettle? Y'know you're a fire hazard? This is the third one!
answer: I never hear the whistle.

question: Feed the dogs.
answer: You want to go through those? I'm taking them to the Thrift Shop. It's Marcia Vaughn's pet charity. Pick out what you want to keep -- it's mostly your city clothes.

question: I used to wear this to the Garden. Garbage strikes. Dog shit. Muggers. Ship it.
answer: Don't be silly - You're going to make summer better for them...

question: On the swing? I told you not to play near there until I sanded it down. See what your son did?
answer: Go upstairs and bring Mommy a band- aid. Don't forget these.

question: Oh, yeah. How do I look? Older, huh?
answer: I think they make you look sexy.

question: Sexy, hm? What was I before?
answer: Older, sillier.

question: I don't want to depend on these things, y'know - sometimes you can weaken your eyes. Let's see... Brody... yeah, what's up... mmm... Well, what do they usually do, float or wash up? Really?... okay, I'll meet both of you at the beach in ...20 minutes, okay? Okay. First goddamn weekend of the summer.
answer: There. What was that?

question: The office.
answer: Be careful.

question: Here? You gotta be kiddin'. Love ya.
answer: Hey Chief. Bring my cup back.

question: Christine what?
answer: Worthingsly... Worthington -- no one ever died on me before.

question: You picked her up on the ferry.
answer: I didn't know her.

question: And nobody else saw her in the water?
answer: Somebody could've -- I was sort of passed out.

question: Think she might've run out on you?
answer: Oh, no, sir. I've never had a woman do that. I'm sure she drowned.

question: You from around here?
answer: No. Cambridge. Harvard. My family's in Tuxedo, New York, though.

question: You here for the summer?
answer: Some friends and me took a house.

question: What d'you pay for a place just for the summer?
answer: A thousand apiece, something like that. There's five of us. And we each kick in a hundred a week for beer and cleaning, stuff like that.

question: Pretty stiff. Maybe that's your girl.
answer: You can't make me look -- !

question: If this is going to work, you've got to keep current stuff out here, and put 'closed' files in there. The 'Pendings' stay on my desk, okay?
answer: This is in no order of importance, Chief Searle's Rent-a-Bike, the Rainy Ale, Tisberry's Hardware... they say it's those nine-year-olds from the school practicing karate on all those nice picket fences. It's the Coroner. Somebody pass away in the night?

question: Jesus, Santos. leans forward, staring at what he just wrote. Polly cocks her head and removes the phone from his ear.
answer: What's the matter?

question: Polly, I want to know what water recreation is on for today.
answer: Right this minute?

question: Where'd you hide the 'Beach Closed' signs?
answer: We never had any. What's the problem?

question: Call me later in the day, okay, Harry?
answer: Polly told me to tell you there's a scout troop in Avril Bay doing the mile swim for their Merit Badges. I couldn't call them in, there's no phone out there.

question: Get out of there  take these back to the office and make up some 'Beach Closed' signs, and let Polly do the printing.
answer: What's the matter with my printing?

question: What's the matter with my printing?
answer: What have you got there, Lenny?

question: We had a shark attack at South Chop this morning, Mayor. Fatal. Gotta batten down the beach.
answer: Who've you told this to, Lenny?

question: I just found out about it -- but there's a bunch of Boy Scouts in the water a coupla miles down the coast from where we found the girl. Avril Bay, thereabouts. Chief went to dry them off.
answer: Take my car, okay? You come with us, Lenny.

question: I've got all these signs here...
answer: C'mon, it'll give us time to think about what they're going to say. Martin! Are you going to shut down the beach on your own authority?

question: I don't think you can appreciate the gut reaction people have to these things.
answer: I was only reacting to what I was told.

question: It's all psychological, anyway. You yell 'Barracuda' and everyone says 'huh'. You yell 'Shark' and we've got a panic on our hands. I think we all agree we don't need a panic this close to the 4th of July.
answer: I can't work in a vacuum. Why don't you make Hendricks Chief? His family's been here since the Puritans -- half this island are his cousins.

question: Do you want the boys to come in? Honey, if you're worried...
answer: How's the water?

question: You're very tight, y'know? Right there.
answer: Ow. He's gotta be more careful in the water...

question: What is it...?
answer: Michael! Sean! Out of the water. Everybody out of the water! Michael! Get out!

question: I'll get to that in a minute. First, I plan to start our seasonal summer help early, and to use shark spotters on beaches open to the sea. I'd like cooperation from local fishermen, and I've also contacted the Oceanographic Institute over on the mainland.
answer: No need to involve outsiders in our business, Martin.

question: Larry and I have also decided to close the beaches for a short time.
answer: Only 24 hours!

question: his reading glasses reflecting a stack of twelve library books, all on the subject of sharks and shark attacks. The door opens and Ellen enters, quietly, in respect for Brody's mood.
answer: Can you stand something to eat?

question: Love a cup of tea. With lemon.
answer: Mikey loves his birthday present.

question: Where is he?
answer: He's sitting in it. Honey. He has it tied up to the jetty with a double-knot.

question: I want him out of the ocean.
answer: It's three feet deep, Martin

question: Michael! Come inside!
answer: It's his birthday present, and you closed the beach, Honey. I told him not to go in the water after what happened yesterday. I don't believe he'll ever do it again.

question: I told him not to go out until he memorized the handbook and the safety safety regulations, until he was sure of himself...
answer: You heard your father! Out right now!

question: You wanna call it a night after here?
answer: It's only two-thirty. What, are you tired?

question: Yeah, Charlie, I got my second wind three nibbles back. Leg of lamb this time?
answer: Screw lamb -- let's shoot the sirloin!

question: We're blowin' half the bounty on bait -- One more after this, then I'm going home.
answer: Set? Tide's taking it right out.

question: You do this all the time, right, Charlie?
answer: Twenty years.

question: I can't believe that people pay money to go fishing. This is really dumb. This isn't even relaxing... it's just boring. Hey! What's this?
answer: Look at him take it!

question: Do I set the goddam hook?
answer: Let him do it! Go-go-go-go-go!

question: CHARLIE! JUMP!
answer: Holy Jesus Christ!

question: Looks more like the readers of the National Enquirer. Hey! You know how many men that's supposed to hold? What you got ain't safe. You take some guys off or you don't go out.
answer: Hello.

question: You going out too, Ben? Just back up! No, the other way! Cut it to your left! Your other left! The big boat, your front end is out way too far. Little boat, stay still!
answer: Ahoy, sail! You got an oar? Well, scull it out! Just cast off in turn and make for the channel, OK?

question: Thanks.
answer: Excuse me, I wonder if you could tell me... Is that dynamite?

question: If that's dynamite, give it here, or don't leave port. Hand it over.
answer: There's a fantail launch out there that won't make it beyond the breakwater.

question: You're tellin' me. I swear, this town has gone crazy.
answer: Officer, I wonder if you could tell me where I could find Chief Brody?

question: Who are you?
answer: Hooper, Matt Hooper. From the Oceanographic Institute.

question: Let's show Mr. Hooper our accident.
answer: Victim One, identified as Christine Watkins, female Caucasian... ...height and weight may only be estimated from partial remains. Torso severed in mid-thorax, eviscerated with no major organs remaining. May I have a drink of water? Right arm severed above the elbow with massive tissue loss from upper musculature. Portions of denuded bone remaining. -- did you notify the coast guard?

question: No, it was local jurisdiction.
answer: Left arm, head, shoulders, sternum and portions of ribcage intact. Please don't smoke. With minor post- mortem lacerations and abrasions. Bite marks indicate typical non-frenzy feeding pattern of large squali, possibly carchaninus lonimanus, or isurus glaucas. Gross tissue loss and post-mortem erosion of bite surfaces prevent detailed analysis; however, teeth and jaws of the attacking squali must be considered above average for these waters. -- Did you go out in a boat and look around?

question: No, we just checked the beach...
answer: It wasn't an 'accident,' it wasn't a boat propeller, or a coral reef, or Jack the Ripper. It was a shark. It was a shark.

question: Here... one red, one white. Ummm. Really good.
answer: My husband tells me you're in sharks.

question: I wouldn't put it that way. But I love sharks.
answer: You love sharks?

question: Thank you.
answer: Here's to your husband, the only other rational man on the island. Day after tomorrow, I'll be gone, and he'll be the only one.

question: You're leaving?
answer: Going out on the 'Aurora.'

question: Is that a boat?
answer: Is it! The best-funded research expedition to ever study the shark... around the world in 18 months.

question: Like those Cousteau specials on television? I think it's for the kids, but I love them.
answer: Better than Cousteau, or Compagno with computers, telemetry, Defense Department funding...

question: I saw a show with sea otters, and a big turtle... Mikey loved it. Made me promise to get him one. Will you live on the boat?
answer: Yep.

question: Drowning. Lemme ask you something. Is it true most attacks take place in three feet of water, around 10 feet from the beach?
answer: Yeah. Like the kid on your beach. I wish I could've examined that shark they caught...

question: Something else. Do most attacks go unreported?
answer: About half of them. A lot of 'missing swimmers' are really shark victims.

question: There's a kind of a lone shark, called, uh...
answer: Rogue?

question: Yeah. Rogue. Picks out an area where there's food and hangs out there as long as the food supply lasts?
answer: It's called Territoriality. It's a theory.

question: And before 1900, when people first starting swimming for recreation, before public bathing and resorts, there were very few shark attacks, cause sharks didn't know what they were missing?
answer: You could say that.

question: I am Chief of Police. I can do anything I want. You want to come?
answer: I'm flattered you should ask. ...And it was Dartmouth Winter weekend, and she was Homecoming Queen, and I was her date; then she got into the fact that her family had more money than my family, and she was right -- her great-grandfather was in mining, and my ancestors were Yankee shipbuilders. So we broke up and I went home with some beatnik from Sarah Lawrence.

question: What stinks so bad?
answer: Our friend, the shark. We always had a summer place on the water -- Newport, the Vineyard, so I figured I'd major in something I knew about. Oceanography, marine biology. It was that, or design racing yachts like my older brother. Hmmm. He we go. Up the old alimentary canal. Hold the light. We open the abdominal cavity and check the digestive tract. Simple.

question: What's that?
answer: Half a flounder. Hmmm... a burlap bag... a paint can... aha!

question: What? What?!
answer: Just as I thought. He drifted up here with the Gulf Stream, from southern waters.

question: How can you tell?
answer: Florida license plate.

question: He ate a car?
answer: No, but Tiger sharks are the garbage cans of the ocean. They eat anything. But this one didn't eat any people. There's nothing here... ...Nothing.

question: What do we do?
answer: If you're looking for a shark, you don't look on land. You go out and chum for him.

question: Chum?
answer: Only one sure way to find him -- offer him a little something to eat. Chum -- blood, waste meat, fish, anything. They can sense it miles away. If he's out there, we might be able to get a closer look at him. It's a good time, too. They're night feeders... That's the Cape Light -- we're on the stretch where he's feeding, if he's still here.

question: What is all this stuff?
answer: Depth-finder, fathometer, sonar, closed-circuit TV -- fore and aft -- RDF, single side band... And two loose nuts behind the wheel.

question: Can you tell from that if a big man- eater is around?
answer: Sometimes. Look here -- something big, probably a school of mackerel clumped together. And staying right with us.

question: Where'd you get all this?
answer: I Bought it. Both sets of grandparents set up trust funds for me; stocks went up, so I don't have to touch my principal.

question: You're at the Institute full time? Or do you have a job?
answer: It is a job. I'm not fooling around like some amateur. It's my life!

question: We gotta get back soon... Hey! What the hell? That's Ben Gardner's boat! It's the Flicka! Ben? Ben! What happened?
answer: I want to check something. Hold my feet.

question: Don't they have lifejackets or something? An extra boat?
answer: They must've hit something. He didn't have a dinghy aboard. I'm going down to take a look at his hull.

question: Why don't we just tow it in?
answer: We will. There's something I've got to find out.

question: You all right?
answer: A White! A Great White, I found a tooth buried in the hull. He must've attacked... I knew it... Gardner's dead in there. I didn't see the mate...

question: No shark did that to a boat!
answer: Jesus Christ! A Great White! Who'd believe it! We're not talking about a shark, we're talking about a Shark!

question: There is a kind of shark called a Great White Shark that every expert in the world agrees is a maneater.
answer: You're situation here suggests that a Great White has staked out a claim in the waters around Amity Island, and that he will continue to feed here as long as there is food in the water.

question: There's no limits to where he can strike, and we've had three attacks and two deaths in the past few days. It happened like this before, in 1916, when a Great White killed five swimmers at Jones Beach, in Long Island.
answer: A shark's attack is stimulated by the kind of splashing and activity that occurs whenever humans go swimming -- you can't avoid it!

question: A 4th of July beach is like ringing a dinner bell, for Chrissake!
answer: I just pulled a shark tooth the size of a shot glass out of the hull of a wrecked boat out there.

question: Hey Mikey -- ! You're not going to the ocean with that, are you son?
answer: I'm all checked out for light surf and look at it.

question: Do me this favor just once. Use the ponds.
answer: Dad, the ponds are for old ladies.

question: Just a favor for your old man.
answer: Sure, Dad.

question: No. Home here. Got a pen on you?
answer: Why?

question: There's only one thing you're good for anymore -- signing a damn voucher. Here. It's an authorization to employ a contractor.
answer: I don't know if I can do that without a...

question: I'm going to hire Quint to kill the fish. I want to see that shark dead.
answer: Maybe we can save August...

question: Forget it. This summer's had it. Next summer's had it. You're the mayor of Shark City. You wanted to keep the beaches open. What happens when the town finds out about that?
answer: I was acting in the town's best interests...

question: The best interest in this town would be to see that fish belly-up in the water with a hole in his head. You do the right thing. You authorize me. Right there. Whatever it costs.
answer: My kids were on that beach...

question: Did you bring a check?
answer: What?

question: Cash? Or do we do this on a handshake and a promise?
answer: I'm authorized by the township of Amity to hire you as an independent contractor. We'll meet your price. $10,000.

question: And my regular daily rate -- $200, whether we catch him or not.
answer: You got it.

question: And incidental damages, if any...
answer: You got it.

question: And you get the Mayor off my back with this zoning crap. Nobody tells me how to run my property.
answer: You got it.

question: And, uh, a case of apricot brandy and you buy the lunch.
answer: Two cases. And dinner when you land.

question: I've been to sea since I was 12. I've crewed three Trans-pacs --
answer: Transplants?

question: -- and an America's Cup Trials...
answer: I'm not talking about day sailing or pleasure boating. I'm talking about working for a living. Sharking.

question: And I'm not talking about hooking some poor dogfish or sand shark. I'm talking about a Great White.
answer: Are you now. I know about porkers in the water -- Here. Tie me a sheepshank.

question: I don't need to pass basic seamanship.
answer: Let me see your hands... Ha. City hands. You been counting money. If you had a $5000 net and $2000 worth of fish in it, and along comes Mr. White, and makes it look like a kiddy scissors class has gone to work on it and made paper dolls. If you'd ever worked for a living, you'd know what that means.

question: Hey. Knock it off. I don't want to have to listen to this while we're out there...
answer: What do you mean 'We...?'

question: It's my charter. My party.
answer: All right, Commissioner. But when we're on my ship, I am Master, Mate and Pilot. And I want him... ...along for ballast.

question: You got it.
answer: 5 lengths of 1/2-inch, 20 number 14's, straight gaff, flying gaffs, tail rope, eye splice, M-1, 20 clips, pliers, irons...

question: 5 lengths of 1/2-inch, 20 number 14's, straight gaff, flying gaffs, tail rope, eye splice, M-1, 20 clips, pliers, irons...
answer: Powerhead, CO2 darts, hypo, regulator, tanks, depth gauge, camera, extra magazines, cage... All of it. And thank Dr. Miro for me. And tell Borack I'll catch up with them in New Zealand. An eye for an eye, you know.

question: Hey, Squirt! You want to stow this gear or you want me to use it for ballast? It ain't good for much but bait.
answer: I'll see ya. Tell Dorothy hello.

question: Hello, Junior. What are you? Some kind of half-assed astronaut? Jesus Christ, when I was a kid, every little squirt wanted to be a harpooner or a sword fisherman. What d'ya have there -- a portable shower?
answer: Anti-Shark cage.

question: Who's inside, you or the shark? You're in the cage? The cage is in the water? The shark is in the water too? You're in the water with the shark.
answer: Comin' aboard...

question: Is that him?
answer: Colorful, isn't he?

question: You going to be all right?
answer: Nothing to worry about -- I'll survive this.

question: Nobody. We're drifting with the current.
answer: Nothing. Nothing, nothing, nothing.

question: Hell, in the old days we went out with good charts, good sounding lead, and a damn good compass. Nowadays, these kids are afraid to go out without depth finders, radar, radio, electric toothbrush, every stupid thing... Get a fresh barrel.
answer: Watch it! Compressed air -- you screw around with one of those and Boom! Careful, huh?

question: Real fine stuff but it won't mean a thing to Mr. Whitey, of course... he didn't go to schools in electronics. He was born with what he does best. Eat. He's a swimming appetite. 'Course he might eat this stuff, but then I've seen him eat a rocking chair, too. Next time, ask me.
answer: That's pilot whale, isn't it?

question: Get behind me, dummy! Reverse her and turn -- he's taking too much line! Wet my reel, quick! Starboard, for Chris'sake -- Hey, you! Farmer! Half-speed there...
answer: Aye, Aye SIR. Stand by to repel boarders. Poop the mainsail. Argh, Jim Boy.

question: Neutral! Where the hell is he going? Oh, this ain't foolin' me -- Sure -- try it! Makin' believe it's easy now. Gettin' ready to run again -- no? No? What's he playin' here? Put the gloves on! Let's see who's gonna tease who now!
answer: Let it go, don't waste your time.

question: Down here, Hooper!
answer: I don't know what it is, but it's not a shark.

question: Unbuckle me -- fast! Grab the leader. He ain't normal, this one... they never --
answer: It's too wild, too erratic. It's a marlin or a stingray. It's a gamefish.

question: Watch your hands -- Grab onto this! A marlin, or a stingray. Huh. Don't ever tell me my business again. Get back up on the bridge.
answer: I'm okay...

question: Fasten the pole.
answer: What's the point with hooks and Lines? --

question: Don't tell me my business! Quarter-mile, that way. Full throttle.
answer: How -- if they're gonna keep on breaking?

question: There's a formula! Girth, about 150 inches, squared, divide by 800 -- son of a bitch, they are not going to believe this! -- divide by 2000... three tons! You're right, you old fart! Three tons!
answer: Orca here. Put her on. This is Quint, Missus. He's busy. Just fine, Missus. We'll be back soon. Everything's fine. We haven't seen anything yet. Orca out.

question: Damn it! I need something in the foreground to give it some scale. Martin! Stand here! No, to your left!
answer: Here. Rig this to the forward keg up there. Get up there and steer her. Follow my hand, and hold 'er steady. I've got to get a clean shot at that porker's head. Hurry up, rig the line! Come to port. Watch my hand. Steady now... The line, man, the line! Get clear, damn you!

question: Clear!
answer: Jesus H. Christ On a Crutch! Now you've done it, you piss-ant. Stop and rig a goddam tinker toy to my gear. Let the bastard fight the keg for a while. He can't stay down with that on.

question: You hired me, remember? It's my $10,000. It's my shark... He's up again. That's not so bad. Look at this
answer: Look here. Steve Kaplan bit me during recess.

question: Wire burn. Trying to stop a backstay from taking my head off.
answer: Moray Eel. Bit right through a wet suit.

question: Face and head scars come from amateur amusements in the bar room. This love line here... ...that's from some crazy Frenchie come after me with a knife. I caught him with a good right hand right in the snot locker and laid him amongst the sweetpeas.
answer: Ever see one like this? Bull shark scraped me while I was taking samples...

question: Nothing! A pleasure scar. Look here -- Slammed with a thresher's tail. Look just like somebody caressed me with a nutmeg grater...
answer: I'll drink to your leg.

question: And I'll drink to yours. Wait a minute, young fella. Look. Just look. Don't touch... ...Mako. Fell out of the tail rope and onto the deck. You don't get bitten by one of those bastards but twice -- your first and your last.
answer: I think I can top that, Mister... Gimme a hand, here. I got something to show you -- There. Right there. Mary Ellen Moffit broke my heart. Let's drink to Mary Ellen.

question: And here's to the ladies. And here's to their sisters; I'd rather one Miss than a shipload of Misters. Look a' that -- Bayonet Iwo Jima.
answer: C'mon. Middle appendix --

question: I almost had 'im.
answer: What's that one, there?

question: The bilge pumps. There -- Cut the engines!
answer: Rudder bearings?

question: Get up forward! Watch for him! Keep your eyes open, Mr. Hooper! Nobody sleeps! Nobody. Show me the way to go home... I'm tired and I want to go to bed. More left rudder! More! Left hand down now, Chief.
answer: Lemme get a better angle on it. Now.

question: No way! He can't!
answer: Where'd he go?

question: He can't stay down with three barrels on him! Where is he?!
answer: Have you ever had one do this?
